metadata.title: Effect of the redox properties of support oxide over cobalt-based catalysts in high temperature water-gas shift reaction

Editor’s choice paper Effect of the redox properties of support oxide over cobalt-based catalysts in high temperature water-gas shift reaction Ajay Jha a Yeol-Lim Lee a Won-Jun Jang a Jae-Oh Shim a Kyung-Won Jeon a Hyun-Suk Na a Hak-Min Kim a Hyun-Seog Roh a ⁎ Dae-Woon Jeong b ⁎ Sang Goo Jeon c Jeong-Geol Na c Wang Lai Yoon d ⁎ a Department of Environmental Engineering, Yonsei University, 1 Yonseidae-gil, Wonju, Gangwon 26493, South Korea Department of Environmental Engineering Yonsei University 1 Yonseidae-gil Wonju Gangwon 26493 South Korea b School of Civil, Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Changwon National University, 20 Changwondaehak-ro, Changwon, Gyeongnam 51140, South Korea School of Civil Environmental and Chemical Engineering Changwon National University 20 Changwondaehak-ro Changwon Gyeongnam 51140 South Korea c Biomass and Waste Energy Laboratory, Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER), 152 Gajeong-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 34129, South Korea Biomass and Waste Energy Laboratory Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER) 152 Gajeong-ro Yuseong-gu Daejeon 34129 South Korea d Hydrogen Laboratory, Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER), 152 Gajeong-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 34129, South Korea Hydrogen Laboratory Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER) 152 Gajeong-ro Yuseong-gu Daejeon 34129 South Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The present study focused on the effect of reducibility of support oxide (CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2, and Al2O3) over the activity of cobalt-based catalysts in high temperature water-gas shift (HT-WGS) reaction. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and CO chemisorption characterization results showed that dispersion of cobalt over the support was increased with the increase of the reducibility of the support oxide. The supported catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and N2 adsorption–desorption. The results indicated that the Co/CeO2 catalyst possesses the highest surface area and metal dispersion in the series; Co/CeO2 >Co/ZrO2 >Co/Al2O3 >Co/TiO2. The activity results showed that Co/CeO2 was the highly active among the tested catalysts in the temperature range of 350–550°C. Moreover, the time-on-stream study revealed that the Co/CeO2 catalyst was relatively more stable than cobalt supported on ZrO2 and Al2O3 oxides. The excellent activity and stability of the Co/CeO2 catalyst were attributed to its high metal dispersion, which is found strongly dependent on the reducible nature of the support. Keywords CeO2 Cobalt Water-gas shift ZrO2 Al2O3 1 Introduction The removal of CO from syngas to produce high–purity hydrogen through the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction has garnered increased attention in the fuel cell industry to generate electrical energy with high efficiency and low environmental impact [1]. The WGS reaction is a catalytic process that involves oxidation of CO to CO2 (using labile oxygen of the catalyst) followed by oxidation of the reduced catalyst by H2O to produce H2. The reaction is moderately exothermic (ΔH=−41kJ/mol), reversible, and thermodynamically limited at high temperatures, and kinetically controlled at low temperatures [2]. The WGS reaction is industrially performed over Fe-Cr catalyst for high temperature shift (HTS) at 350–500°C and Cu-Zn-Al catalyst for low temperature shift (LTS) at 190–250°C [3]. However, due to the potential environmental concerns related to Cr, recent investigations have focused on the development of Cr-free catalysts for the HTS reaction [4]. Currently, cobalt-based catalysts have drawn large amount of attention in various chemical transformations such as Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, the oxygen evolution reaction, hydrodesulfurization, photocatalytic water oxidation, and a large set of C1 chemistry reactions (CO oxidation and dry reforming of CH4) [5–9]. The outstanding performance of cobalt oxide in these reactions is attributed to the weaker bond strength of Co–O (bond length=1.934Å and 1.963Å for Co3O4) and the low hopping barrier for oxygen at the surface compared to other 3d transition metals (bond length=1.81Å for CuO; and bond length=1.89 and 2.06Å for Fe3O4) [10–13]. This observation has led to the investigation of cobalt-based catalysts as a substitute for Fe-Cr catalysts, which are employed in HTS reactors. The literature survey shows that cobalt has been used in the WGS reaction as a sulfur–resistant catalyst [14,15]. Recently, Majima et al. investigated K/Co3O4 catalyst for the WGS reaction. They found that addition of K in Co3O4 increased the activity and stability of the resulting catalyst [16]. We previously found that doping of cobalt into ceria was effective for improving the activity and stability of Co3O4 catalysts in the HTS reaction [17]. The time-on-stream study revealed that the Co/CeO2 catalyst was highly stable compared to bulk Co3O4. The stable performance of the Co/CeO2 catalyst was attributed to the water dissociation ability of ceria, which makes cobalt stable under HTS reaction conditions. To further verify the role of ceria in WGS reaction, we prepared a series of cobalt–based catalysts using the same composition over different support oxides. The reducibility of cobalt, crystallite size, dispersion, and number of active cobalt metal sites are crucial factors to influence a chemical reaction. These variables are directly related to the nature of the support oxide as well as to the interaction between cobalt and the support. The effect of the support on the catalytic performance can occur via direct participation of the support or by an indirect role (e.g., by influencing the morphology and size of the supported metal particles, by charge transfer between the metal and support oxide, or by stabilizing the supported ionic metal species) [18]. Zhao et al. performed studies on cobalt supported on various metal oxides (ZrO2, CeO2, SiO2, Al2O3, and TiO2) for the preferential oxidation (PROX) of CO [19]. Their results showed that Co/ZrO2 possessed the highest CO oxidation activity; this was related to the highest dispersion of cobalt in the Co/ZrO2 catalyst. Ozkan et al. investigated cobalt–based catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3, TiO2 and ZrO2 in a bio-ethanol steam reforming reaction. They found that the ZrO2–supported catalyst exhibited the best dispersion and the best catalytic performance in the reaction [20]. Thus, to investigate how the nature of the support can influence cobalt–based catalysts in the HT-WGS reaction, we have prepared a series of supported cobalt catalysts by varying the reducible and non-reducible support oxides. CeO2, ZrO2, and TiO2 oxides were selected as reducible supports and Al2O3 was selected as a non-reducible support. The activity and time-on-stream study revealed that the ceria–supported cobalt catalyst is preferable for the HTS reaction among the tested catalysts. Based on the characterization and activity results, the effects of the support on cobalt–based catalysts was discussed and elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O), aluminium nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) average Mn ∼5800, 1-butanol (C4H9OH) titanium (IV) tert–butoxide (Ti[OC(CH3)3]4 cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) and nitric acid (HNO3) were purchased from the Sigma-Aldrich, South Korea. Zirconyl nitrate trihydrate ZrO(NO3)2·3H2O was supplied by South Korea. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis A series of cobalt-based catalysts with 15wt.% cobalt loadings on various supports were synthesized by the incipient-wetness impregnation method. All of the support oxides, including CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2, and Al2O3, were prepared by the inverse micelle sol-gel method [21]. Synthesis of the support oxides involved dissolution of 0.02mol of the corresponding metal precursors into a solution of 2.0g P123 surfactant, 1.6mL HNO3 acid, and 14.0g n-butanol. The resulting mixtures were stirred for 24h to obtain clear gels, which were placed in an oven at 120°C for 6h to dry. Next, the powder material was calcined at 500°C for 6h. The as obtained solid materials were used as supports for cobalt catalysts. The nitrate precursor of cobalt (0.755g equivalent to the 15wt.%) was dissolved in 0.5mL of distilled water and the prepared solution was impregnated over the 0.85g of calcined support oxide. The impregnation process was performed in 5–6 times repeatedly to load all of the precursor solution. Between two successive steps, the sample was dried at 100°C for 1h in the oven. Finally, the catalyst was dried at 100°C for 12h and then calcined at 500°C for 6h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The BET surface area was measured by nitrogen adsorption at −196°C using ASAP 2010 (Micromeritics). XRD patterns were recorded using a Rigaku D/MAX–IIIC diffractometer (Ni filtered Cu–Kα radiation, 40kV, 100mA). The XRD measurement conditions were as follows: slit size=2.5°, step size & time per step: 0.02° step/0.5s. Prior to XRD measurement, all of the catalysts were reduced at 400°C under a 5% H2 flow (30mL/min) for 1h to investigate which phase of the metallic cobalt (i.e. hcp or fcc phase) is available for the WGS reaction. The crystallite size of metallic cobalt was estimated using the Debye-Scherrer equation. The reducibility and strength of the metal-support interaction in the catalysts were evaluated through H2-TPR. The H2-TPR experiments were conducted on an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritics). Typically, 0.1g of sample was loaded into a quartz reactor and reduced with 10% H2 in Ar from room temperature to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The sensitivity of the detector was calibrated by reducing a known weight of NiO. The dispersion of cobalt on various support oxides was measured by CO chemisorption at 50°C using an Autochem 2920 instrument (Micromeritics). The calcined catalyst was reduced at 400°C for 1h in 10% H2/Ar flow. After that, catalyst was cooled down to 50°C. Then, CO pulses [CO/He=10/90 (vol.%)] were passed to the catalyst surface till they were saturated with CO. The amounts of CO adsorbed on the metallic cobalt were calculated from the decrease in the peak area of CO due to its adsorption on the catalysts. From the chemisorbed amount, the cobalt dispersion was calculated by assuming the adsorption stoichiometry of 2 CO per cobalt surface atom (CO/Co=2). The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of samples were performed from 50 to 900°C with a (TGA/DSC 1 STARe system SF 1100) instrument under the flow of O2 at a heating rate of 10°C−1. 2.4 Catalytic reaction The activity of the prepared catalysts was measured from 350°C to 550°C at atmospheric pressure in a continuous-flow, fixed-bed micro-tubular quartz reactor. Typically, 30mg of catalyst was loaded into a reactor (length=600mm and i.d.=4mm). The length and volume of a packed catalyst bed were 3.5mm and 175.9mm3, respectively. The length/diameter ratio of the reactor was 150 (600mm/4mm). A T-union was employed at the exit of the quartz reactor to install a thermocouple. The thermocouple was inserted into the catalyst bed to measure the reaction temperature. Prior to each catalytic measurement, all of the catalysts were reduced by 5% H2/N2 from room temperature to 400°C at a heating rate of 4.6°Cmin−1. The temperature was then maintained for 1h. After the temperature was lowered to 350°C, the simulated reformed gas (consisting of 38.0% CO, 21.33% CO2, 2.30% CH4, 29.30% H2, and 9.07% N2, which is representative of typical syngas from a waste gasifier) was fed into the WGS reactor. The flow rate of the feed gas and water were 31.95sccm and 1.9mL/h, respectively. In the presence of water, concentration of the gases will change. The actual concentration of the gases enters into the WGS reactor was: CO=17.02%, CO2 =9.55%, CH4 =1.03%, H2 =13.12%, and N2 =4.06%. The feed H2O/[CH4 +CO+CO2] ratio was fixed at 2.0. A GHSV of 143,000mL/gcat h. was used to screen all of the catalysts. Water was fed into the reactor using a syringe pump, vaporized at 180°C upstream of the reactor. The product gas was chilled, passed through a trap to condense the residual water, and then analyzed online using an Agilent micro-gas chromatograph. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 XRD result XRD patterns of the reduced Co/CeO2, Co/ZrO2, Co/TiO2, and Co/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . Co/CeO2 shows XRD peaks at 2θ=28.5, 33.0, 47.4, 56.2, 59.2, 69.3, 76.7, and 78.9°, suggesting the presence of fluorite-structured CeO2. For the Co/ZrO2 sample, the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 was observed, as evidenced by the sharp peak at 2θ=30.3° [22]. The XRD pattern of Co/Al2O3 demonstrates the amorphous γ-Al2O3 phase of alumina. The diffraction pattern of Co/TiO2 shows the anatase phase of titania, as evidenced by an intense peak at 2θ=25.1° [23]. In addition to the oxide phases of the corresponding supports, the XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts exhibit two small diffraction peaks at 2θ=41.5 and 44.3°. These peaks correspond to the hcp (100) and fcc (111) phases of metallic cobalt, respectively [24]. The differaction peaks related to the Co3O4 were absent in the XRD pattern of these catalysts, indicating that only the metallic phase of cobalt available for the HTS reaction. Using Scherrer’s equation, the crystallite size of the metallic cobalt in the reduced catalysts was estimated from the (111) diffraction line at 2θ=44.3°. The corresponding values are summarized in Table 1 , which revealed that all of the reduced catalysts exhibited similar crystallite sizes for the metallic cobalt (20±2nm). 3.2 BET and CO chemisorption results The surface areas of the supported cobalt catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms; these corresponding values are included in Table 1. The surface areas of these catalysts varied by small values, suggesting that the surface area is strongly influenced by the preparation method and not due to the different source of the precursors used in catalyst preparation [25–27]. Among the prepared catalysts, Co/CeO2 showed the highest BET surface area (23m2/g), while the Co/TiO2 showed the lowest value (13m2/g). The metallic cobalt-specific surface area (MSA) in the supported cobalt catalysts was measured using CO chemisorption at 50°C (Table 1). The increasing order of MSA in the supported cobalt catalysts is; Co/TiO2 <Co/Al2O3 <Co/ZrO2 <Co/CeO2. The ceria supported cobalt catalyst showed the highest MSA value (5.16m2/g) within this series, which may be related to the higher degree of cobalt reduction. However, the Co/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the lowest value (0.65m2/g), which was even less than cobalt supported on the non-reducible support (γ-Al2O3). The lower MSA value of Co/TiO2 catalyst can be attributed to the compound formation ability of cobalt with titania [28]. 3.3 H2-TPR result H2-TPR experiments were performed to investigate the reducibility of the supported cobalt catalysts; these corresponding results are shown in Fig. 2 . The reduction profile of these supported catalysts provides guidelines for the dispersion of cobalt over the support and the extent of the interactions between cobalt and the support oxides. The steps involved in the reduction of cobalt oxide to metallic cobalt can be written as follows [29]: Co3O4 +H2 →3CoO+H2O (First step) 3CoO+3H2 →3Co°+3H2O (Second step) Fig. 2 shows that the cobalt supported on metal oxides can be reduced at relatively low temperatures compared to bare cobalt oxide (Co3O4) (ESI=Fig. S1). The TPR profile of Co/CeO2 shows two peaks at 243 and 286°C, which were thought to represent the reduction of highly dispersed Co3O4 and CoO, respectively [30]. TPR profile of bare ceria oxide shows two reduction peaks at 450 and 720°C (ESI=Fig. S2). These two peaks were not clearly distinguishable in Co/CeO2 catalyst due to the broad nature of the peak. Co/ZrO2 exhibited three reduction peaks near 256, 284, and 535°C. These peaks primarily belong to the reduction of Co3O4, CoO, and the surface labile oxygen of ZrO2, respectively [31]. The TPR profile of Co/TiO2 also displayed three reduction peaks at 264, 305, and 410°C, which can be attributed to the reduction of Co3O4, CoO, and the interaction compound between Co and TiO2, respectively [32]. The TPR profile of unsupported ZrO2 and TiO2 showed single reduction peaks at 768 and 512°C, respectively (ESI=Fig. S2). These reduction peaks were shifted to lower temperatures after cobalt was supported over them. This indicates a synergistic effect between cobalt and the support oxides, which lowers the reduction temperature of both cobalt and the support. Co/Al2O3 exhibited three overlapping reduction peaks at 267, 284, and 321°C, which correspond to the reduction of Co3O4, CoO, and the CoO bonded with the γ-Al2O3 oxide, respectively [33]. TPR profile of the bare alumina oxide did not show any peak, indicating its non-reducible nature. By comparing the reducibility of cobalt on various supports, it can be observed that the reduction of cobalt on ceria starts at a much lower temperature than the other supports, suggesting the higher extent of dispersion and interaction of cobalt with ceria oxide. Another reason for the enhanced reducibility of the Co/CeO2 catalyst might be associated with the diffusion of cobalt ions into the ceria lattice, which provokes charge imbalance and lattice distortion in the ceria structure [34–36]. This would induce defect sites and/or oxygen vacancies in the catalyst, thereby facilitating the reduction of cobalt. Quantitative estimation of the hydrogen consumption of the supported cobalt catalysts was performed by measuring the area under the TPR curves. For this purpose, the peaks related to cobalt oxide reduction were only considered. The trend of hydrogen consumption in the supported cobalt oxide catalysts follows the order of; Co/TiO2 (0.62mmol)<Co/Al2O3 (0.90mmol)<Co/ZrO2 (1.15mmol)<Co/CeO2 (1.20mmol). These results showed that the cobalt oxides supported on reducible metal oxides have higher hydrogen consumption values than those of the cobalt supported on the non-reducible oxide (with the exception of Co/TiO2). The lowest H2 consumption value for the Co/TiO2 catalyst can be attributed to the compound formation ability of cobalt with titania [28]. 3.4 Catalysts activity result The high temperature WGS reaction was performed over the supported cobalt catalysts to investigate how the redox properties of the various support oxides influence the catalytic performance. The WGS activity profiles of these catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The Co/CeO2 catalyst showed the highest CO conversion for the entire tested temperature range (350–550°C). Co/ZrO2 and Co/Al2O3 were the next most active catalysts, and the lowest reactivity was seen for the Co/TiO2 catalyst. The outstanding activity of the Co/CeO2 catalyst might be related to the higher cobalt dispersion, which would allow for the highest coverage of reactant gas on the surface, thereby facilitating the reaction. At lower temperatures (<450°C), the catalytic activity was found to be directly proportional to the dispersion of metallic cobalt over the support, which is related to the redox properties of the support oxides. To show this correlation, we plotted a graph between the CO conversions of various supported cobalt catalysts and the dispersion of cobalt, as shown in Fig. 4 . It demonstrate that as the reducibility of the support oxide increases, metal dispersion on the support also increased via the appropriate metal–support interactions and this lead to the enhanced CO conversion. Table 1 shows that although Co/ZrO2 and Co/Al2O3 catalysts have almost same surface area, the former shows higher cobalt dispersion than the latter. This observation suggests that, in addition to the surface area, the reducibility of the support oxide also plays a vital role in cobalt dispersion. In our study, the dispersion of cobalt over the various support oxides follows the order of; Co/TiO2 <Co/Al2O3 <Co/ZrO2 <Co/CeO2. The same trend is observed for the reducibility of these catalysts. Among the supported cobalt catalysts, Co/CeO2 showed the highest metal dispersion. This might be the result of the strong redox property of CeO2 compared to ZrO2 and TiO2. The lowest metal dispersion in the Co/TiO2 catalyst was due to the compound formation ability of cobalt with titania, which decreased the number of active sites of the metallic cobalt. This also explains the lowest activity of the Co/TiO2 catalyst within this series. Fig. 3 also shows that the conversion of CO increases with increasing temperature until equilibrium is reached at 550°C (except for the Co/TiO2 catalyst). This is attributed to the redistribution of oxygen vacancies from the bulk to the surface, which occurs upon exposure of catalyst to water vapor at high temperatures. Since the cobalt-based catalyst is active for the hydrogenation (Fischer-Tropsch synthesis) reaction, therefore, we plot the product selectivity result as shown in Fig. 5 . It shows that only Co/Al2O3 and Co/TiO2 produced methane at lower temperatures. However, Co/CeO2 and Co/ZrO2 are highly selective towards the WGS reaction in the entire temperature range. It has been observed that pristine CeO2 is not active in the WGS reaction. Thus, in the Co/CeO2 catalyst, cobalt is the active participant in the WGS reaction. To investigate the nature of cobalt (i.e. either the metallic or oxide phase of cobalt is active in the reaction), we performed the WGS reaction separately over bare Co3O4, reduced at 400 and 250°C, under 5% H2 (Fig. 6 ). The purpose of using bare Co3O4 was to avoid any side influences of the support on the reduction of cobalt oxide. The activity test showed that Co3O4 reduced at 400°C was active, while the Co3O4 reduced at 250°C was inactive in the HTS reaction. The XRD patterns of the spent cobalt oxide reduced at 400°C exhibited a majority of the metallic phase of cobalt along with CoO while sample reduced at 250°C displayed mixed phase of CoO and Co3O4 (Fig. 7 ). These observations clearly suggest that only the metallic phase of cobalt is active in the HTS reaction; partially reduced cobalt (CoO) and Co3O4 were catalytically inactive. This result can be attributed to the weaker adsorption of CO (one of the reactant gas) on the partially reduced CoO surface, which was desorbed without additional reaction. On the basis of the XRD patterns of the used Co3O4 samples under different reduction conditions, we are providing possible pathways for the WGS reaction. Fig. 8 shows a schematic illustration of the WGS reaction over cobalt–based catalysts. Primarily two mechanisms have been proposed in the literature for the WGS reaction: (1) the redox mechanism and (2) the associative mechanism [37–39]. However, the redox path is dominant at high temperatures [37]. In the redox mechanism, CO is adsorbed onto the metal-support interface where it takes an oxygen from the support to produce CO2 and form an oxygen vacancy. Subsequently, water replenishes the generated oxygen vacancy and produces H2. Ribeiro et al. reported that the oxide support directly participates in the dissociation of water molecules; reducible supports are especially effective at water dissociation due to the fact that they contain oxygen vacancies [18]. However, pure metal oxide supports are incapable for water dissociation [40]. Although oxygen vacancy sites facilitate water dissociation, the presence of an active metal species is always required to support this processes. As we discussed previously, the formation of an oxygen vacancy is a concomitant process of CO oxidation, which depends on the molecular interactions between CO and the d-band of a surface metal atom. Generally, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of CO forms a sigma bond with a surface metal atom. Afterwards, through back donation, the metal atom shares its π-orbital electron density with CO. This type of π-back donation may not be possible in the case of partially reduced cobalt oxide, where the electron density is already shared with a bonded oxygen atom (making it unavailable for incoming CO molecules). Therefore, the adsorption of CO can not be facilitated by partially reduced cobalt oxide, which leads to catalytic inactivity in the WGS reaction. 3.5 Catalyst stability test At higher temperatures (>450°C), cobalt supported on CeO2, ZrO2, and Al2O3 exhibited almost the same activity. Based on this result, it is hard to say which is the promising catalyst for the HTS reaction. Therefore, a time-on-stream study was conducted at 450°C at a GHSV of 143,000mL/gcat h to compare the effect of support on the stability of catalysts. These results are shown in Fig. 9 . It was observed that the supported cobalt catalysts were initially more active; however, the catalytic activity of cobalt decreased with time. The catalysts show the following order of the stability: Co/CeO2 >Co/ZrO2 >Co/Al2O3. Co/ZrO2 catalyst showed rapidly loss in CO conversion from 86 to 40% after 30h of stability test. However the rate of decrement was slower for the Co/CeO2 and Co/Al2O3 catalysts. The loss of activity can be attributed to cobalt sintering or to coke formation through the Boudouard reaction (2CO↔CO2 +C) [41]. The XRD results of the spent catalysts revealed the increase of the crystallite size of metallic cobalt, but this increment was similar for all three catalysts (25±2nm). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to measure the coke formation in spent catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . It was observed that the Co/ZrO2 catalyst undergoes 11% carbon weight loss at 400°C, while Co/CeO2 and Co/Al2O3 showed negligible weight loss. This indicates that the rapid loss of activity in the Co/ZrO2 catalyst was primarily due to the deposition of carbon after 30h of the reaction. On the contrary, the decrease of activity in the Co/Al2O3 and Co/CeO2 catalysts was associated with the oxidation of metallic cobalt to CoO, which was caused by the long exposure of catalyst to water vapor [42]. The formation of CoO was detected at 2θ=35.6° in the XRD pattern of the spent Co/Al2O3 and Co/CeO2 catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 11 . However, the intensity of the CoO peak was much less in Co/CeO2 compared to the Co/Al2O3 catalyst, suggesting the slow formation rate of CoO in the Co/CeO2 catalyst. The relatively high stability of Co/CeO2 (compared to Co/ZrO2 and Co/Al2O3 catalysts), as shown in Fig. 8, was due to the presence of oxygen vacancies in CeO2; these promote water dissociation and increase oxygen mobility [43]. The adsorbed carbon on the Co/CeO2 surface was oxidized to CO2 using labile oxygen, thereby keeping the surface clean and active for the HTS reaction. 4 Conclusions Cobalt supported on CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2, and Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method and their performances in the HTS reaction were compared. The Co/CeO2 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity and stability performance among the series. The reducibility of the support oxide was found to play a main role in influencing the catalytic performance of the cobalt-based catalysts. Support oxides with higher reducibility favor higher cobalt dispersion, which leads to the exposure of more surface active metal sites and enhances the WGS activity. CeO2 was found to be the most suitable support for cobalt–based catalysts to catalyze the HTS reaction. Co/CeO2 showed the best metal dispersion, highest CO conversion, and was more stable in the time-on-stream study than the ZrO2−, Al2O3−, and TiO2− supported cobalt catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The present study focused on the effect of reducibility of support oxide (CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2, and Al2O3) over the activity of cobalt-based catalysts in high temperature water-gas shift (HT-WGS) reaction. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and CO chemisorption characterization results showed that dispersion of cobalt over the support was increased with the increase of the reducibility of the support oxide. The supported catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and N2 adsorption–desorption. The results indicated that the Co/CeO2 catalyst possesses the highest surface area and metal dispersion in the series; Co/CeO2 >Co/ZrO2 >Co/Al2O3 >Co/TiO2. The activity results showed that Co/CeO2 was the highly active among the tested catalysts in the temperature range of 350–550°C. Moreover, the time-on-stream study revealed that the Co/CeO2 catalyst was relatively more stable than cobalt supported on ZrO2 and Al2O3 oxides. The excellent activity and stability of the Co/CeO2 catalyst were attributed to its high metal dispersion, which is found strongly dependent on the reducible nature of the support.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of the redox properties of support oxide over cobalt-based catalysts in high temperature water-gas shift reaction
